newsitem.title: USA: CSCE cocoa called to open $25 to $35 higher.
newsitem.headline: CSCE cocoa called to open $25 to $35 higher.

text.p: CSCE cocoa futures were called to open $25 to $35 higher Thursday on the heels of a strong performance in London overnight, traders said.
LIFFE cocoa futures surged to 10-week highs in heavy trade Thursday on fears the El Nino weather pattern would damage next year's crops.

At midsession, LIFFE benchmark July stood 37 stg higher at 1,062 stg a tonne, its highest level since April 4. Second-position September was up the same at 1,082 stg after climbing over resistance at 1,072 stg.

Earlier this week, U.S. National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA) said warm ocean temperatures off the western coast of South America had triggered an El Nino Weather pattern, which could bring dry damaging weather to cocoa-growing areas.

Wednesday, New York cocoa futures rose sharply, bolstered by chart-driven speculative buying. Spot July settled up $36 at $1,471 a tonne after trading from $1,472 to $1,426. Second-month September closed $37 higher at $1,514, while the outer months finished up $30 to $34.
Traders said July cocoa broke through all resistance levels on Wednesday's close.
